stem: The nurse assesses a 24-year-old female client during a follow-up visit. Highlight the cues that are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
passage: A 24-year-old female is being evaluated for chronic fatigue and joint pain. The nurse observes a flat, red rash across the bridge of the patient's nose and cheeks. The client reports that the rash 'gets much worse' after she spends time in the sun. She also mentions having painful, swollen joints in her fingers and wrists that are worse in the morning. Physical exam reveals small, painless ulcers on the hard palate of the mouth. Laboratory results show a positive Antinuclear Antibody (ANA) titer. The client says she has always had regular menstrual cycles. Her heart rate is 78 bpm. She reports that she recently started a new job and is feeling stressed.

rationale.correct: Characteristic signs of SLE include the malar (butterfly) rash, photosensitivity, polyarthritis (joint pain/swelling), oral ulcers, and a positive ANA titer (found in >95% of patients).
rationale.incorrect: Regular menstrual cycles and heart rate are normal findings. Stress is a common trigger for flares but is not a diagnostic cue of the disease itself.

reviewUnits.heading: SLE Diagnostic Criteria
reviewUnits.body: Diagnosis involves clinical findings (Malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, arthritis, serositis, renal disorder, neurologic disorder) AND immunologic markers (ANA, Anti-dsDNA, Anti-Smith).

clinicalPearls: The malar rash typically spares the nasolabial folds, which helps distinguish it from rosacea.

mnemonic.title: SOAP BRAIN MD
mnemonic.expansion: Serositis, Oral ulcers, Arthritis, Photosensitivity, Blood disorder, Renal disorder, ANA positive, Immunologic markers, Neurologic disorder, Malar rash, Discoid rash.

answerBreakdown.label: Critical Cues
answerBreakdown.content: The identified evidence represents objective clinical markers of physiological instability.
